subsection.title: Basics for lines
subsection.p: Let L be a line in the x,y-plane that is not vertical (that is, not parallel to the y-axis). Visualize traveling along the line L from a starting point (A,B) to a final point (P,Q). From start to finish, your position along the x-axis will change from A to P. The deviation of P from A (also called the horizontal displacement from (A,B) to (P,Q)) is called the run of your trip. \text{ run } = P-A Likewise, your position along the y-axis will change from B to Q. The deviation of Q from B (also called the vertical displacement) is called the rise of your trip. See Figure . \text{ rise } = Q-B The fraction rise/run is called the slope of the line L. \text{ slope } = \frac{ \text{ rise }}{\text{ run }}=\frac{Q-B}{P-A} Solving for rise, we have \text{ rise } = { \text{ (slope)}}{\text{(run) }} and solving for Q, we have Q=\text{ (slope)(run)} + B = \text{ (slope)}(P-A)+B.
Here is a basic problem involving lines: You are given a line L, the slope m of L, a starting point (A,B) on L, and the x-coordinate P of a final point (P,Q) on L. Your task is to find Q.

The solution uses broken into three these steps:
Find the run using \text{ run } = P-A.
Find the rise using \text{ rise } = \text{ (slope)(run)}.
Find Q using Q=\text{ rise } + B.
